results.title: Musicanada
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Malca Gillson and Tony Ianzelo
results.brief_description: With no commentary other than the music and words of the performers themselves, this fast-moving film presents the grandest Canadian concert of them all. Here, the performers include both the great and the unknown from across the country, the musical styles span the centuries, and the artists are involved in all stages of musicianship: learning, teaching, conducting, recording, performing. Among the film’s many stars are Edith Butler, Beau Dommage, Maureen Forrester, Glenn Gould, Paul Horn, the Huggett Family, and Gilles Vigneault. (Award: San Francisco)

results.title: Musical Tales
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Bennett, John Hosier and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: This beautifully animated puppet film presents four of your favourite stories set to the great classical music of Tschaikovsky, Stravinsky and Delibes. Featurees “The Nutcracker and the Mouse King”, “Petrushka”, “Coppelia” and “Sleeping Beauty”.

results.title: Musical notes
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Frank Wells and S.G. Fergusson
results.brief_description: Investigates first the vibration of strings and the relation between pitch and frequency, amplitude and loudness and the variation of frequency with tension, length and thickness of the strings. The variation of pitch with length of air column is considered in relation to the woodwind instruments. Percussion instruments are also discussed.

results.title: Musical Max
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Paul R. Gagne and Virginia Wilkos
results.brief_description: Max is a musical hippo - “you name the instrument, and Max can play it”. Max practiced a vast variety of instruments, much to the annoyance of his father and the neighbours. Only Max’s mother loved the constant stream of music, which finally stopped at night when everyone had to go to sleep. One day, Max wakes up, and decides that he is not in the mood to play or practice any more. At first, everyone is relieved to finally have some peace and quiet, but gradually the silence starts driving Max’s father crazy. Eventually, the neighbours find a solution to the problem, and Max gets his groove back in a spectacular fashion. From the book by Robert Kraus, illustrated by Jose Aruego and Ariane Dewey.

results.title: Musical forms: the fugue (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Dissects the Fugue in G minor and explains various components, analyzing a typical fugue. Sight and sound are co-ordinated by an animated score and sufficient repetition is built in to enable the components to be learned.
results.description: Dissects the Fugue in G minor and explains various components, analyzing a typical fugue. Sight and sound are co-ordinated by an animated score and sufficient repetition is built in to enable the components to be learned.

results.title: Musical forms: the canon (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Uses animation and live-action photography to illustrate the various elements of a canon. Also explores the variations of this musical form from the classical canon to a contemporary rock canon.

results.title: Music professor
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bernard Devlin and Gil LaRoche
results.brief_description: A Saturday afternoon spent with a piano teacher shows the patience, hope, disappointments, frustrations, and occasional joy and satisfaction which are part of the job.

results.title: Music of the spheres
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Time-Life Films, Adrian Malone and Dick Gilling
results.brief_description: Jacob Bronowski discusses the influence of mathematics and numbers on culture throughout the ages. Going back to the time of Pythagorus, he demonstrates how his mathematical formula influenced Greek music and thought; how it was adapted in Alexandria by people such as Ptolemy; the development of symmetry art and culture; to the translation of numerical thought into Latin and its effect on perspective, depth and dimension in art. Throughout, it is stressed by Bronowski how the inner eye of the painter and the logic of the mathematician have combined in the development of art and culture. Written and narrated by Jacob Bronowski. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC-TV, Time-Life Films, Adrian Malone and Dick Gilling

results.title: Music of the masters: 'Jesu, joy of man's desiring' Bach
results.brief_description: Prayerful lyricism of this Bach piece celebrated in H. Dexter’s sensitive arrangement for chamber trio (David Martin - violin; Barnard Richards - cello; Marie Goosens - harp). Delicate graceful gestures of the players are an apt counterpoint to the beauty of the music.
